visibility_factors: overcast ceiling lowering vis at times

alert_summary.description: Ice-jam flooding risk along the Muskegon River in Newaygo County through 7:00 PM Monday (Feb 2). Not a direct school-road hazard for Rockford, but relevant for low-lying river areas/commutes through Newaygo.

meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford on Monday 2026-02-02, this looks like a cold but manageable Michigan winter day. Temperatures stay well below freezing (low-to-mid teens early, rising toward ~20°F by late morning). The key point: there is essentially no snow during the overnight/bus window (roughly 6–8 AM), so roads should be in their best condition at pickup time. The only notable visibility issue is mist/low clouds early (visibility down near ~1 mile at times around 5–6 AM and again late evening), which can slow buses but usually does not cause closures by itself. The only accumulating snow signal is a brief late-morning snow shower around ~11 AM totaling about 1.6 cm (~0.6") for the entire day—this is not close to a Michigan closure threshold. Winds are light to modest (max ~12 mph), so blowing/drifting is not a concern. Wind chills during bus time are around 7–9°F (nowhere near the -15°F to -20°F closure-trigger territory). Net: very low snow-day probability; at most, expect a normal on-time start with cautious driving in patches of reduced visibility from mist.

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Light, cold snow event (around 0.5–1.5 inches) with temps in the teens/20s and modest wind (<15 mph). Snow arrives after the morning commute window and is brief (late morning).

Cold, saturated low-level air with morning mist/fog (1–3 mile visibility at times) but little/no precipitation during bus time; temps well below freezing so any untreated slick spots can persist on bridges/secondary roads.

“Forecast says ‘moderate/heavy snow showers’ but total snow stays under ~2 inches” — typically scattered bursts with localized quick coatings; closures only if a band hits exactly 6:30–7:30 AM and roads are already marginal.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Early February in West Michigan is peak winter readiness: plow/salt operations are fully ramped, buses and drivers are in full winter mode, and communities are generally tolerant of light snow. A 1–2 inch daytime snow is usually a ‘normal winter day’ rather than a closure trigger in the Rockford/Grand Rapids area.
unusual_factors: Visibility reductions from mist/fog around daybreak (reported 1–3 miles at times) can elevate crash risk even without much snow.
Very cold pavement (teens) means any slush refreezes quickly; slick bridges/overpasses and shaded rural roads are the usual problem spots.

A regional Flood Advisory for an ice jam (near Newaygo/Muskegon River) is hydrology-focused; it typically does not drive school closures unless it creates specific roadway flooding/closures in-district.

local_microclimates: Rockford sits NE of Grand Rapids; rural edges and low-lying areas can hold fog longer than the urban core.
North/east of town can run a touch colder, increasing the odds that any light precip bonds to roads.
If a narrow snow shower band sets up, totals can vary sharply over a few miles (common in West Michigan).
infrastructure_considerations: Rockford-area districts generally handle 1–3 inches without closing, especially when it’s not falling hard during the 6:30–7:30 AM bus window.
Main arterials and treated routes are usually fine; the ‘decision drivers’ are rural bus routes, hills, and bridges if there’s a quick glaze or sudden burst of snow.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Minor-to-moderate: small elevation changes can matter for fog/black ice pockets, but this setup does not suggest a major elevation-driven snow jackpot.

history.confidence_assessment: For Monday, February 2, 2026 in Rockford, MI, the forecast supports a LOW snow-day probability. Total snow is only ~1.6 cm (~0.6 in) with light winds and no snow indicated during the critical morning commute hours; the main watch-out is localized slick spots from cold temps and reduced visibility from morning mist. In Michigan, events with <1 inch of snow and no ice typically close schools only about 5–15% of the time; given the timing (snow closer to late morning) and modest winds, I’d center this near ~10% for a full-day closure, with a slightly higher ‘caution’ for minor delays if fog/black ice is observed on rural routes.

safety_recommendations: Snow-day likelihood driver is NOT accumulation—it's patchy slick spots from fog/mist and low visibility on rural roads before sunrise (approx. 05:00–08:00).

Expect primary roads (US-131/M-57 type corridors) to be in good shape for the AM run; biggest concerns shift to neighborhood streets, gravel, and shaded connectors where a thin glaze/black ice can form.
Have transportation do an early (pre-5:30 AM) spot-check of known trouble areas: bridges/overpasses, low spots near creeks, and hill/curve bus-route segments.

If early buses report slipping/poor braking, the best operational lever here is a **1–2 hour delay** rather than a full closure, because temps rise through the morning and any treatment has time to work.
Parking lots/sidewalks: prioritize scraping/salting drop-off loops and bus compounds—thin ice is more likely than deep snow, and falls are the main school-property risk.
Communications: remind families to expect slick sidewalks/driveways and allow extra stopping distance; encourage students to use traction footwear/cleats if they walk.
Monitor the midday snow shower window (~11:00) for localized bursts that briefly coat untreated surfaces; this is more relevant for midday programs than the AM start.
Flood Advisory in Newaygo County is largely not a Rockford road-closure driver, but any travel northwest toward Newaygo should respect barricades/closures around low-lying river-adjacent roads.

local_news.headline: Plow drivers work eight consecutive days as heavy snow blankets Kent County
local_news.summary: FOX 17 reports that residents in Cedar Springs, Sparta, and Rockford woke up to school closures and about 6 inches of new snow, with Kent County Road Commission plows dealing with heavy snowfall/drifting and whiteout conditions. The piece also notes crews hoped to be caught up with most roads cleared by Wednesday evening, and reminds drivers to keep distance behind plows.

local_news.source: Rockford Public Schools (Rockford, MI) – Superintendent Update
local_news.headline: 1/27/26 Superintendent Update discusses ongoing challenging winter conditions and decision process
local_news.summary: The superintendent explicitly notes January’s challenging weather and that the extended forecast is 'not encouraging.' He describes the district’s early-morning road-check process (mechanic driving roads E–W/N–S, operations leaders tracking plows/sidewalk clearing, transportation team input). This is a strong indicator they’re in active winter-operations mode and considering closures/delays as conditions warrant.

local_news.source: Forest Hills Public Schools (neighboring district) – District Calendar page alert
local_news.headline: Forest Hills Public Schools closed Tuesday, Jan. 27 due to inclement weather (banner alert)
local_news.summary: FHPS posted a prominent closure alert stating the district was closed on Tuesday, Jan. 27 due to inclement weather, with childcare open and after-school activities canceled. This is a nearby-district 'domino' signal that conditions in the broader area have recently met closure thresholds.

local_news.headline: Krause Memorial Library to relocate to the Community Cabin during expansion construction (reopens Feb. 2)
local_news.summary: Not a closure signal by itself, but it confirms community logistics on Feb. 2 (the temporary library location opens Feb. 2 at the Rockford Community Cabin). If school is closed/delayed, this kind of planned event may still be impacted locally.

official_announcements: As of the most recently crawled Rockford Public Schools district site content, there is no posted 'Closed/Delayed for Monday, Feb. 2, 2026' announcement in the district news feed or homepage alert area (only schedule items like Mid-Winter Break and general updates).

Rockford Public Schools superintendent’s 1/27/26 update highlights ongoing severe winter conditions and details the district’s road-check and decision process (suggesting they are actively evaluating travel safety during this stretch of weather).
Neighboring Forest Hills Public Schools posted that it was closed Tuesday, Jan. 27 due to inclement weather (recent regional closure precedent).
neighboring_district_closures: Forest Hills Public Schools: Closed Tuesday, January 27 (inclement weather) (banner alert on FHPS site).

reported_road_conditions: FOX 17 described whiteout conditions, heavy snowfall and drifting, and plow crews working extended shifts in the Rockford/Cedar Springs/Sparta area (recent event context).

news.key_findings_summary: For Monday, 2026-02-02 in Rockford, MI (Rockford Public Schools), I did not find a definitive, dated closure/delay announcement for Feb. 2 on Rockford’s official district site in the material that was publicly crawlable at this time. However, there are strong contextual signals that the region has been experiencing significant winter impacts recently: (1) the RPS superintendent’s 1/27/26 update emphasizes challenging January weather and an 'not encouraging' extended forecast while detailing the district’s early road-check and plow-monitoring process, and (2) a nearby district (Forest Hills) posted a closure on Tue 1/27 due to inclement weather, which often correlates with similar conditions across north/east Kent County. FOX 17 also recently reported heavy snow (~6 inches new) and whiteout/drifting conditions affecting Rockford and neighboring communities with school closures that morning, reinforcing that roads/plowing conditions have been severe in the immediate area. Net: no official Feb. 2 closure found yet; community/neighbor signals suggest elevated risk of a delay/closure if the storm cycle continues into Sunday night/Monday morning.

clearing_timeline.estimated_road_condition_at_6_30_am: Roads should be generally passable: dry/cold conditions overnight with possible mist/fog at times (reduced visibility and isolated slick patches are the main risk, not snow cover).

infrastructure.overall_clearing_assessment:
Based on the provided Rockford, MI forecast for Monday 2026-02-02, there is no meaningful snow accumulation indicated before school bus routes (~6:30 AM). The only accumulating snow signal is late morning (~11:00 AM) with about 1.6 cm (~0.6 in). That timing strongly favors roads being passable for the morning commute, so plow operations should be minimal overnight and focused only on spot-treatment if fog/mist creates slickness.

Real-time road-clearing intelligence: I attempted to pull live MI Drive conditions/snowplow tracker status, but the MI Drive site failed to load via my tool (fetch error). I could confirm from MDOT materials that Mi Drive is the official place to view state trunkline plow locations/cameras, and MDOT’s West Michigan Transportation Operations Center monitors Kent County freeways and publishes camera locations through Mi Drive. I did not find a current (today/this afternoon) Kent County Road Commission plowing status bulletin in the accessible sources, so the ‘plow activity’ and ‘resource level’ assessments are inferred from typical operations + the low overnight snow need rather than direct operational postings.

webWeatherVerifier.verification_summary: For Rockford, Michigan and the target school day Monday 2026-02-02: Your WeatherAPI forecast indicates a relatively typical cold winter morning (temps ~18–19°F at 6–8 AM; feels-like ~7–8°F) with light snow arriving late morning (~0.6 in total). Web sources are inconsistent: one Weather.com hourly page and The Weather Network show a MUCH colder regime (subzero air temps and feels-like around -14 to -16°F at 6–8 AM), while another Weather.com hourly snapshot appears stale/possibly mismatched and shows much milder conditions. None of the credible sources checked here showed ≤ -20°F wind chill during 6–8 AM on Mon 2026-02-02, so the automatic closure trigger is NOT confirmed. Because the web sources diverge by >10°F in apparent temperature, you should treat the colder web guidance as the risk-bound for decision-making until you verify with an official NWS point forecast for the exact Rockford location/ZIP.

final.decision_rationale:
All six inputs converge on a low-impact Monday morning for Rockford: light snow totals (~0.6") with the first meaningful snow arriving after the start of school (around ~11 AM), and light-to-moderate winds. The only credible morning hazards are patchy fog/mist reducing visibility and the possibility of isolated black ice on untreated neighborhood/rural roads, bridges, and shaded curves—conditions that more commonly lead to targeted mitigation or (at most) a short delay if early route checks confirm slipping.

Key conflict resolved: the Web Weather Verifier flagged a large discrepancy in ‘feels-like’ temperatures between WeatherAPI and some web pages. Follow-up meteorology synthesis indicates the more internally consistent solution is NOT arctic: 6–8 AM air temps roughly upper 20s to near 30°F with 12–18 mph winds, yielding wind chills in the teens. No credible pathway to ≤ -20°F wind chill exists with these temperature/wind ranges, so the automatic extreme-cold closure rule is not triggered.

Second-order/community signals: News intel found no active closings/delays on FOX17’s system and no dated Feb 2 closure/delay notices on Rockford or neighboring district pages checked—so there is no domino pressure toward closing. Infrastructure ground truth is limited (MiDrive fetch issues), but both forecast timing and typical operations support main roads being serviceable for the AM run; localized slick spots remain the only meaningful risk. Power-grid conditions are supportive of normal operations; outages appear low and decreasing.

Net: full-day closure remains unlikely; the more realistic disruption mode is a 1–2 hour delay if early-morning route checks detect widespread patchy ice or visibility is materially worse than expected.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Most likely: Schools OPEN on time with caution (spotty slick patches/low visibility early; late-morning light snow)
alternative_scenarios.impact: Normal operations; remind drivers/students about reduced visibility and slick sidewalks/bridges.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Borderline morning: 1–2 hour DELAY due to widespread patchy black ice or fog reducing visibility below safe bus thresholds
alternative_scenarios.impact: Improves safety by allowing daylight + treatment; avoids unnecessary full closure.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Low-probability: FULL CLOSURE due to unexpected widespread glaze, multi-vehicle crashes/road blockages, or a localized major outage affecting a key school facility
alternative_scenarios.impact: Would be driven by ground-truth deterioration rather than forecast snow totals.

for_schools: Recommendation: OPEN with monitoring; be prepared to pivot to a 1–2 hour delay if 5:00–6:00 AM route checks find widespread slipping or very poor visibility.
Run transportation spot-checks by ~05:15–05:45 on known trouble spots (bridges/overpasses, hills/curves, shaded rural segments, subdivision connectors).
If any delay is needed, decide/communicate by ~06:00 to reduce family disruption.
Have custodial teams pre-treat entrances, drop-off loops, and bus compounds for thin ice (bigger hazard than snow depth).
Monitor the ~11 AM snow-shower window for localized quick coatings that could affect midday programs and building-to-building travel.
for_residents: Plan for reduced visibility and possible patchy black ice 5–8 AM; slow down and increase following distance, especially on neighborhood streets and bridges.
Bundle for wind chills in the teens (uncomfortable but not extreme-cold closure territory); ensure students at stops have face/hand coverage.
Watch for updated district messaging early morning in case a short delay is triggered by route checks.
for_authorities: Prioritize pre-treatment/spot-salting on bridges, overpasses, and shaded curves before 6 AM; fog + subfreezing temps can create surprise slick patches.
If the late-morning snow shower develops, be ready for quick-response treatment on untreated side streets and school-zone approaches around 10:30–12:30.
Continue monitoring for any localized ice-jam flooding road impacts northwest of Rockford (Newaygo-direction travel), though it is not expected to be a district-wide driver.

positions.rationale:
Meteorologically, Monday (2026-02-02) looks like a low-impact winter day for Rockford, MI: subfreezing temps all day, light winds, and only a small accumulation signal (~0.6") that occurs late morning rather than before the start of school. That combination strongly favors a normal opening, with the primary operational risk being localized slick spots from freezing fog/mist and briefly reduced visibility on rural bus routes. Those hazards can sometimes trigger a 1–2 hour delay if observed at 5–6 AM, but they rarely justify a full-day closure without heavier snow/ice or much worse visibility.

Net: I’m placing full snow-day probability in the single digits, while acknowledging a non-trivial “delay” risk if fog/black ice is worse than modeled.
keyFactors: Snow timing: essentially no accumulating snow during the critical bus/commute window (~05:30–08:00); the only modeled accumulation is a brief late-morning burst around ~11:00 totaling ~1.6 cm (~0.6").
Snow amount: ~0.6" for the whole day is well below typical West Michigan closure thresholds, especially with winter operations fully active.
Wind/blowing snow: max winds ~12 mph and gusts ~15–18 mph are not supportive of drifting/whiteout; this is a “visibility from mist/low cloud” morning, not a blizzard setup.

Cold: temps teens to near 20°F in the morning; wind chills roughly single digits to low teens in the WeatherAPI hourly profile—uncomfortable but not near common wind-chill closure trigger territory (often closer to -15°F to -20°F).

Visibility: intermittent 1–3 mile visibility in mist/low cloud around daybreak can elevate crash risk on rural routes and bridges, but fog alone more commonly yields delays/caution rather than full closure.

positions.rationale: My historical-analog baseline for Rockford, MI on Monday, Feb 2, 2026 with ~0.6" forecast snow and light winds is a low closure probability (~5–10%). I’m nudging slightly upward to ~12% because (1) there are credible signals of recent severe winter conditions in the region (which can leave lingering packed snow/ice on secondary roads), and (2) the forecast includes early-morning mist/low visibility that can coincide with patchy black ice—historically the most common reason for a short-notice delay/closure in otherwise ‘light snow’ setups. Still, absent heavy snow during the bus window, significant ice accretion, or extreme wind chills, a full snow day is not the typical outcome.
keyFactors: Historical tolerance in West Michigan: early February operations are typically fully ramped; sub-1" snowfall events with light wind rarely produce full-day closures in Rockford/Grand Rapids-area districts.

Timing: the only meaningful accumulating snow signal is late morning (~11:00), after the critical 6:30–7:30 AM bus window, which historically shifts outcomes toward “open” (at most a delay if conditions are surprise-bad at dawn).

Cold-but-not-extreme (per provided WeatherAPI): morning temps ~18–19°F with wind chills ~7–9°F are uncomfortable but usually below closure-trigger relevance; the bigger historical driver is road traction, not cold exposure, unless wind chills plunge well below zero.

Localized morning visibility/black-ice risk: mist/low visibility (down to ~1 mile around 5–6 AM) plus teens temps can produce patchy slick bridges/secondary roads—this is the main pathway to a *delay*, and only occasionally a closure if widespread and confirmed by route checks.

Context from NEWS: the area has had recent impactful winter events (closures around ~6" with drifting/whiteouts), which can (a) increase readiness, but (b) also leave residual snowpack/ice on neighborhood streets that makes even light new snow more disruptive than the raw totals suggest.

positions.rationale: From a safety/transport perspective for Monday 2026-02-02 in Rockford, the forecast supports **operating with caution** rather than closing: the expected accumulation is light and poorly timed for a morning shutdown, winds are not a factor, and the main credible hazards are localized black-ice pockets and intermittent low visibility near daybreak. Those hazards more often result in **targeted mitigation** (early spot checks, pre-treating known trouble spots, slower speeds) or a **1–2 hour delay** if early route checks show slipping—rather than a full snow day. I’m therefore placing full-day closure odds in the low teens, while acknowledging a somewhat higher chance of *some* disruption (delay) than the closure number reflects.
keyFactors: Snow/ice amount and timing are not favorable for a full closure: only ~0.6" (1.6 cm) of snow forecast and it’s concentrated late morning (~11:00–12:00), after the main bus run.

Primary commute risk is *patchy* (not widespread): subfreezing temps all day plus saturated low levels (mist/fog) can create isolated black-ice on bridges, shaded rural connectors, and untreated neighborhood streets—usually a delay lever rather than a closure driver.
Visibility dips to ~1 mile around 05:00–06:00 and again late evening; reduced vis increases crash risk for buses on rural routes but commonly remains manageable with slower ops/route adjustments.
Winds are modest (~12 mph max), so no blowing/drifting or whiteout mechanics that typically force closures.
No district-specific “hard stop” safety trigger evident (e.g., widespread ice storm, confirmed sub -20°F wind chills, or heavy snowfall during 06:00–08:00).

Flood Advisory (ice jam) is geographically focused (Newaygo County) and not a primary Rockford school-transport hazard, though it can create isolated road-closure exceptions for families traveling northwest.

positions.rationale: From a “news + district behavior” standpoint, the best signal remains the absence of a dated Feb. 2 closure/delay notice on official RPS channels in the provided materials—suggesting no planned preemptive closure. The weather setup itself (light accumulation, late-morning timing) typically does not produce a snow day in West Michigan. I do, however, keep the probability above “single digits” because local reporting indicates the area has recently had disruptive snow with closures, and because the forecast includes low visibility/mist during subfreezing temps that can create a localized bus-route safety problem (most likely outcome: normal opening or a short delay, not a full cancellation). Net: low chance of a true snow day, modest chance of a delay.
keyFactors: No official Rockford Public Schools closure/delay posted yet for Monday, Feb 2, 2026 (as of the provided district-site crawl); districts often post by ~5–6 AM day-of unless preemptive closure is warranted.

Forecast timing is unfavorable for a snow day: essentially no accumulating snow during the key bus window (roughly 6–8 AM), with the only meaningful snow signal being a late-morning burst (~11 AM) totaling ~0.6" for the day.

Recent local context raises baseline risk a bit: FOX 17 described very recent heavy snow/whiteout/drifting in the Rockford-area with closures, plus the superintendent’s 1/27/26 note that the extended forecast is “not encouraging.” That indicates the district is on high alert and that residual road/side-street conditions could still be marginal in rural parts of the district.

Morning visibility/ice is the main plausible operational trigger: multiple hours show mist/low vis (~1 mile at times around 5–6 AM) while temps stay well below freezing, supporting patchy black-ice risk on untreated secondary roads, bridges, and shaded routes—more consistent with a 1–2 hour delay than a full closure.

Non-snow alerts (Flood Advisory for an ice jam in Newaygo County until 7 PM Monday) are geographically limited and unlikely to drive a Rockford-wide school closure, but they slightly increase uncertainty for students/staff commuting from NW areas.

confidenceJourney.shiftReason:
Meteorologically, Monday (2026-02-02) looks like a low-impact winter day for Rockford, MI: subfreezing temps all day, light winds, and only a small accumulation signal (~0.6") that occurs late morning rather than before the start of school. That combination strongly favors a normal opening, with the primary operational risk being localized slick spots from freezing fog/mist and briefly reduced visibility on rural bus routes. Those hazards can sometimes trigger a 1–2 hour delay if observed at 5–6 AM, but they rarely justify a full-day closure without heavier snow/ice or much worse visibility.

Net: I’m placing full snow-day probability in the single digits, while acknowledging a non-trivial “delay” risk if fog/black ice is worse than modeled.

My historical-analog baseline for Rockford, MI on Monday, Feb 2, 2026 with ~0.6" forecast snow and light winds is a low closure probability (~5–10%). I’m nudging slightly upward to ~12% because (1) there are credible signals of recent severe winter conditions in the region (which can leave lingering packed snow/ice on secondary roads), and (2) the forecast includes early-morning mist/low visibility that can coincide with patchy black ice—historically the most common reason for a short-notice delay/closure in otherwise ‘light snow’ setups. Still, absent heavy snow during the bus window, significant ice accretion, or extreme wind chills, a full snow day is not the typical outcome.

From a safety/transport perspective for Monday 2026-02-02 in Rockford, the forecast supports **operating with caution** rather than closing: the expected accumulation is light and poorly timed for a morning shutdown, winds are not a factor, and the main credible hazards are localized black-ice pockets and intermittent low visibility near daybreak. Those hazards more often result in **targeted mitigation** (early spot checks, pre-treating known trouble spots, slower speeds) or a **1–2 hour delay** if early route checks show slipping—rather than a full snow day. I’m therefore placing full-day closure odds in the low teens, while acknowledging a somewhat higher chance of *some* disruption (delay) than the closure number reflects.

From a “news + district behavior” standpoint, the best signal remains the absence of a dated Feb. 2 closure/delay notice on official RPS channels in the provided materials—suggesting no planned preemptive closure. The weather setup itself (light accumulation, late-morning timing) typically does not produce a snow day in West Michigan. I do, however, keep the probability above “single digits” because local reporting indicates the area has recently had disruptive snow with closures, and because the forecast includes low visibility/mist during subfreezing temps that can create a localized bus-route safety problem (most likely outcome: normal opening or a short delay, not a full cancellation). Net: low chance of a true snow day, modest chance of a delay.

keyDisagreements.topic: The news context about recent 6-inch/whiteout events is useful for ‘background readiness,’ but it can overweight recency. For 2026-02-02 the provided hourly precip/snow signal is light and late-morning; meteorology should dominate over last-week impacts unless you can show lingering untreated roads or a new overnight burst.
positions: The news context about recent 6-inch/whiteout events is useful for ‘background readiness,’ but it can overweight recency. For 2026-02-02 the provided hourly precip/snow signal is light and late-morning; meteorology should dominate over last-week impacts unless you can show lingering untreated roads or a new overnight burst.

keyDisagreements.topic: Labeling ice-formation risk as ‘moderate’ is plausible, but it needs tighter linkage to a mechanism: with no precip during the bus window, the main pathway is freezing fog/deposition on cold surfaces + pre-existing moisture. If that’s the claim, the decision implication is more ‘delay/route adjustments’ than ‘closure.’
positions: Labeling ice-formation risk as ‘moderate’ is plausible, but it needs tighter linkage to a mechanism: with no precip during the bus window, the main pathway is freezing fog/deposition on cold surfaces + pre-existing moisture. keyDisagreements.topic: The WEBWEATHERVERIFIER notes a major discrepancy: some web sources suggest much colder temps/feels-like than WeatherAPI. If the colder solution is correct (e.g., subzero temps with lower wind chills), the risk of persistent black ice and slower bus operations rises—potentially pushing outcomes toward a delay. We should reconcile with an official NWS point forecast before locking confidence.

Right now the evidence supports the former more than the latter given no precip in the bus window.

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 30 at 4:15PM EST until February 2 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to
an ice jam.

* WHERE...A portion of west central Michigan, including the
following county, Newaygo.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Monday.

* IMPACTS...Ice jams are notoriously unpredictable. Low-lying areas
along the Muskegon River that are prone to flooding may see
rapidly changing water levels as ice shifts and adjusts.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 408 PM EST, an ice jam remains in place on the Muskegon
river in southern Newaygo County. The river gauge at Newaygo
shows water levels remaining at minor flood stage as of
Friday afternoon. As temperatures warm this weekend, water
levels should continue to slowly fall. Shorter periods of
rising and falling water levels are expected with any shifts
in the ice.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. While
flooding associated with freeze up ice jams is typically
minor, conditions can change rapidly and unpredictably.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Newaygo.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
alert.instruction:
Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement. Respect any road closures in the area.
